text: Study in Finland | Student Residence Permit 🇫🇮 - Study in Finland | Student Residence Permit 🇫🇮 Student Residence Permit In Finland, as a non-EU/EEA student planning to pursue degree studies, you can apply for a student residence permit for the whole duration of your studies once you have secured admission. Share The student residence permit (student visa) can be granted for the full length of your studies. For research or doctoral studies, you will need a separate residence permit for scientific research, valid for up to two years. Student residence permit (Migri.fi) Researcher residence permit (Migri.fi) Bear in mind that you must prove you have sufficient finances and insurance . Have a look at what we say about funding your studies ! Application Process Once admitted to a Finnish institution, you should start your residence permit application as soon as possible - to ensure you will receive your permit in good time before the start of your studies. Apply through the Enter Finland portal , making sure you have all required documents. After submitting your application online, book and attend an appointment at the nearest Finnish embassy or consulate for identity verification. There is a waiting period while your permit is processed after your embassy visit. Use this time to prepare for your move but keep an eye on your application status through the Enter Finland portal. Before traveling to Finland, double-check that you have all the right documents and stay updated with the Finnish Border Guard for the latest entry requirements. After graduation, you can apply for a two-year permit to seek work or start a business. Permanent residence is possible after four years on a continuous residence permit, including your study period, especially if you are employed post-graduation. For more detailed advice, consult directly with the Finnish Immigration Service (Migri) and the Finnish embassy or consulate in your country.

text: Study in Finland | FAQ 🇫🇮 - Study in Finland | FAQ 🇫🇮 FAQ On this page you will find answers to some frequently asked questions about studying in Finland. Share Are scholarships available for international students? Some Finnish universities may offer scholarships or tuition fee waivers for non-EU/EEA students, so check the possible scholarship options with the university in Finland you're applying to. Note that the universities' scholarships do not as a rule cover any living or travel costs. There are no governmental scholarships available for bachelor's and master's studies in Finland - no such programme as "Fully Funded Finland Government Scholarships" exists. See our article on scholarship facts ! How much will I need to cover my living costs? Finland is a relatively expensive country to live in, so we recommend you reserve approximately €900 – €1200 per month for your living expenses (accommodation, food, travel). Can I work while studying in Finland? International students are allowed to work part-time up to 30 hours per week on average during the academic year and full-time during holidays. Students may also find internships related to their field. However, keep in mind that finding employment is challenging, especially if you do not know Finnish or Swedish - so you should not base your financial plans on the uncertain prospect of finding a part-time job during your studies. Can I bring family members with me? This is possible, but you must take into account that you and your family need to have enough money for living in Finland . While working is allowed for a student's family member, remember it is quite difficult to find employment especially without Finnish or Swedish skills. The universities and student housing foundations also have a limited amount of family apartments available. How do I apply to a university in Finland? You apply through the national portal Studyinfo.fi . The application forms are available online at Studyinfo.fi only during the application periods. See our starter's info on Admissions . When can I apply? Most degree programmes are part of the joint application system, which typically opens in January for studies starting in autumn. In September there is another joint application period, which usually includes a limited amount of studies starting in January. You can check the joint application timetables at Studyinfo.fi . Some degree programmes are not included in the joint application system, but have separate application periods. For example, a number of universities' master's programmes have their admissions open from November or December onwards. Always check the application timetables and other details with the university or UAS you plan to apply to! What are the admission requirements? Requirements vary by programme, so check the details with the university and in the Studyinfo.fi programme descriptions. Generally, you need a relevant upper secondary school certificate for bachelor’s programmes, and a bachelor’s degree for master’s programmes. Master's programmes offered by UAS's (universities of applied sciences) additionally require work experience. Some programmes may require entrance exams or interviews.
